banana.name: Banana, raw
banana.insight: Nature's portable energy bar—rich in potassium and quick carbs, ideal pre-workout fuel but watch portions if managing blood sugar.

balanced.insight: Solid all-around fruit with good fiber (3g) and exceptional potassium (422mg, 12% DV). Moderate natural sugar is the main consideration.

heart_health.insight: Potassium powerhouse (422mg) with virtually no sodium—ideal 422:1 ratio for blood pressure. Zero saturated fat or cholesterol.

muscle_building.insight: Only 1.3g protein won't build muscle, but fast carbs make it ideal post-workout for glycogen replenishment. Always pair with protein.

energy.insight: Fast-digesting natural carbs plus potassium (prevents cramping) and B6 (0.43mg, 25% DV) make this top choice for sustained energy.
cons: May cause energy crash without protein

weight_management.insight: 105 calories is reasonable, but satiety is moderate relative to sugar content. Best paired with protein for better fullness.

brain_focus.insight: Excellent B6 (0.43mg, 25% DV) supports neurotransmitter synthesis including dopamine and serotonin. Quick glucose fuels the brain.
cons: Sugar spike may affect focus later

gut_health.insight: Contains prebiotic fiber and resistant starch (especially when unripe) that feeds beneficial gut bacteria like Bifidobacteria.
cons: Ripe bananas have less resistant starch

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 51 is moderate, but 14g sugar per serving adds up. Choose slightly green bananas for more resistant starch and lower glycemic impact.

bone_joint.insight: Minimal calcium (6mg) or vitamin D. Magnesium (32mg, 8% DV) and potassium provide modest bone support.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Contains antioxidants including dopamine and catechins with mild anti-inflammatory effects. No inflammatory fats.

iron.tip: Pair with vitamin C rich foods

pairWith.reason: Adds protein and healthy fats for better satiety and blood sugar control
Protein slows sugar absorption and adds calcium
Fiber combination keeps you fuller longer

banana.portionVisual: 1 medium banana = size of your fist

tips.storage: Room temperature until ripe, then refrigerate to slow browning (peel will darken but fruit stays fresh)
tips.ripeness: Green = more resistant starch, better for blood sugar; Spotted = sweeter, easier to digest
tips.prepTip: Freeze spotted bananas for smoothies—freezing increases resistant starch content

commonMistakes: Eating too ripe if managing blood sugar (greener is better)
Discarding spotted bananas (they're sweeter and perfect for baking)

cautions.kidney_disease: High potassium (422mg)—limit if on potassium-restricted diet
cautions.diabetes: Count carbs (27g); pair with protein to slow glucose spike

banana.pregnancyNotes: Excellent choice—good folate (24mcg), potassium, and easily tolerated during morning sickness

drugInteractions.reason: Both raise potassium—monitor levels if eating multiple daily

apple.name: Apple, raw, with skin
apple.insight: An apple a day keeps the doctor away—exceptional fiber (4.4g) with polyphenol antioxidants. One of the best low-GI snacks available.

balanced.insight: Great fiber (4.4g, 16% DV), decent vitamin C, and satisfying crunch. Low in most vitamins/minerals but excellent as a whole food snack.

heart_health.insight: Soluble fiber (pectin) actively lowers LDL cholesterol. Polyphenols support arterial health. Low sodium, zero saturated fat.

muscle_building.insight: Only 0.5g protein provides essentially no muscle-building benefit. Useful only as a carb source with protein foods.
cons: Not useful for muscle goals alone

energy.insight: Natural sugars with fiber provide moderate sustained energy. Low GI (36) prevents crashes. Lacks B-vitamins for energy metabolism.

weight_management.insight: Only 95 calories with 4.4g fiber and high water content = excellent satiety. Studies show apples before meals reduce calorie intake.

brain_focus.insight: Quercetin and other polyphenols protect brain cells. Low GI provides steady brain fuel. Lacks omega-3 and B-vitamins.

gut_health.insight: Pectin is a powerful prebiotic fiber that feeds beneficial gut bacteria. 4.4g fiber per apple supports regular digestion.

blood_sugar.insight: Despite 19g sugar, GI is only 36 thanks to fiber and polyphenols slowing absorption. One of the better fruits for blood sugar.

bone_joint.insight: Minimal calcium (11mg), no vitamin D. Some vitamin K (4mcg). Boron content may support bone health modestly.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Quercetin is a potent anti-inflammatory flavonoid. High ORAC score (3049). Keep the skin on—that's where the antioxidants are.
cons: Must eat skin for full benefits

polyphenols.tip: Eat with skin for maximum antioxidants

pairWith.reason: Adds protein and healthy fats—classic combination
Protein and fat slow sugar absorption
Enhances flavor and may help blood sugar control

apple.portionVisual: 1 medium apple = size of a tennis ball

tips.storage: Refrigerate to maintain crispness for weeks; room temp for immediate eating
tips.selection: Firm apples with no bruises; different varieties have different sweetness levels
tips.prepTip: Don't peel—the skin contains most of the fiber and antioxidants

commonMistakes: Peeling the skin (removes most fiber and polyphenols)
Storing at room temperature long-term (they go mealy)

cautions.ibs: High FODMAP for some—may cause bloating in sensitive individuals
cautions.diabetes: Count carbs (25g); GI is low but sugar adds up

apple.pregnancyNotes: Safe and healthy; good fiber helps with pregnancy constipation

pediatric.ageAppropriate: 6+ months (pureed or grated); slices for 12+ months

orange.name: Orange, raw
orange.insight: Vitamin C superstar—one orange provides 116% of daily needs. Excellent immune support with fiber and antioxidants.

balanced.insight: Outstanding vitamin C (116% DV), good fiber (3.1g), decent folate (10% DV). Well-rounded citrus with multiple benefits.

heart_health.insight: Good potassium (237mg), fiber, and flavonoids like hesperidin that support healthy blood vessels. Zero sodium or saturated fat.

muscle_building.insight: Only 1.2g protein—not useful for muscle building. Vitamin C does support collagen synthesis for connective tissue.

energy.insight: Natural sugars with fiber for moderate sustained energy. Thiamin (9% DV) aids energy metabolism. Good hydration from high water content.

weight_management.insight: Only 62 calories with 3.1g fiber and high water content. Very satisfying for the calorie cost.

brain_focus.insight: High vitamin C protects brain from oxidative stress. Flavonoids may improve blood flow to brain. Lacks omega-3.

gut_health.insight: 3.1g fiber plus pectin supports healthy digestion and feeds beneficial bacteria. High water content aids bowel regularity.
cons: Citric acid may irritate sensitive stomachs

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 43 is low for a sweet fruit. Fiber slows sugar absorption. Much better than orange juice for blood sugar.

bone_joint.insight: Good calcium for a fruit (52mg, 5% DV) and vitamin C supports collagen for joints. No vitamin D or K.

anti_inflammatory.insight: High vitamin C and flavonoids (hesperidin, naringenin) have documented anti-inflammatory effects. Good ORAC score.

vitaminC.tip: Eat fresh—vitamin C degrades with time and heat

iron.tip: Eat with iron-rich foods to boost their absorption

pairWith.reason: Vitamin C dramatically increases iron absorption from spinach
Citrus and chocolate complement each other
Adds protein and calcium

avoidWith.reason: May interact with some statins and other drugs—check with pharmacist

orange.portionVisual: 1 medium orange = size of a baseball

tips.storage: Room temperature for a week; refrigerate for up to 3 weeks
tips.selection: Heavy for size indicates juiciness; slight give when pressed
tips.prepTip: Eat the white pith too—it contains additional fiber and flavonoids

commonMistakes: Choosing juice over whole oranges (loses fiber, concentrates sugar)
Removing all the white pith (it's nutritious)

cautions.gerd: Citric acid may trigger reflux in sensitive individuals
cautions.medications: Can interact with certain statins, calcium channel blockers—check with pharmacist

orange.pregnancyNotes: Excellent—high folate (10% DV) and vitamin C support fetal development

drugInteractions.reason: May increase drug levels—less severe than grapefruit but worth noting
May reduce absorption of some antihistamines

blueberries.name: Blueberries, raw
blueberries.insight: The brain berry—one of the highest antioxidant foods on Earth with proven cognitive benefits. Small but mighty.

balanced.insight: Exceptional antioxidants (ORAC 9621), good fiber (3.6g), and modest vitamin K. Low in most minerals but antioxidant density is unmatched.
pros: Highest ORAC score of common fruits

heart_health.insight: Anthocyanins improve arterial flexibility and reduce blood pressure in studies. Good fiber supports cholesterol management.

muscle_building.insight: Only 1.1g protein. Value is in reducing exercise-induced inflammation and oxidative stress—a recovery food, not a building food.

energy.insight: Natural sugars provide moderate energy. Antioxidants may help prevent fatigue. Not particularly high in B-vitamins or iron.

weight_management.insight: Only 84 calories per cup with 3.6g fiber. Studies show blueberries may help reduce belly fat and improve insulin sensitivity.

brain_focus.insight: Proven cognitive benefits in clinical trials. Anthocyanins cross blood-brain barrier, improving memory and delaying brain aging.

gut_health.insight: 3.6g fiber plus polyphenols that feed beneficial gut bacteria. Studies show blueberries increase Bifidobacteria.

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 53 is moderate. Anthocyanins may improve insulin sensitivity. Better blood sugar response than many fruits.

bone_joint.insight: Good vitamin K (28.6mcg, 32% DV) for bone protein synthesis. Anti-inflammatory properties may benefit joints.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Among the most anti-inflammatory foods. ORAC of 9621 is exceptional. Anthocyanins, quercetin, and other compounds powerfully reduce inflammation.

anthocyanins.tip: Frozen blueberries have similar benefits to fresh

pairWith.reason: Protein enhances satiety; probiotics complement polyphenols
Classic combination—fiber synergy
Adds omega-3 for additional brain benefits

tips.storage: Refrigerate unwashed; wash just before eating. Freeze for long-term storage
tips.selection: Deep blue color with silvery bloom indicates ripeness and antioxidant content
tips.prepTip: Frozen blueberries retain most nutrients—great for smoothies year-round

commonMistakes: Washing before storage (promotes mold)
Assuming fresh is always better than frozen (frozen locks in nutrients at peak ripeness)

cautions.warfarin: Vitamin K (32% DV)—maintain consistent intake if on blood thinners
cautions.kidney_stones: Contains oxalates—moderate intake if prone to stones

blueberries.pregnancyNotes: Excellent antioxidant source during pregnancy. Wash thoroughly.

pediatric.chokingRisk: moderate (cut in half for children under 4)

strawberries.name: Strawberries, raw
strawberries.insight: Vitamin C champion with the lowest sugar of popular fruits—only 49 calories per cup. Perfect for weight management and blood sugar control.

balanced.insight: Outstanding vitamin C (149% DV), good fiber, excellent folate (9% DV), and very low calorie. One of the most nutrient-dense fruits.

heart_health.insight: Anthocyanins and ellagic acid improve heart health markers. Good potassium and fiber support cardiovascular function.

muscle_building.insight: Only 1g protein. Vitamin C supports collagen for connective tissue, but not a muscle-building food.

energy.insight: Low-sugar natural energy with good vitamin C. Not particularly high in B-vitamins. Better for sustained energy than quick fuel.

weight_management.insight: Only 49 calories per cup—one of the lowest calorie fruits. 3g fiber and high water content provide excellent satiety.

brain_focus.insight: Anthocyanins and fisetin may improve memory and protect against cognitive decline. Good folate supports brain function.

gut_health.insight: 3g fiber plus polyphenols support a healthy microbiome. Ellagic acid may help protect gut lining.

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 40 and only 7.4g sugar per cup is exceptional for fruit. One of the best fruits for blood sugar management.

bone_joint.insight: Vitamin C (149% DV) supports collagen for joints. Some vitamin K. Manganese for bone health. Low in calcium.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Ellagic acid and anthocyanins are potent anti-inflammatory compounds. ORAC score of 4302 indicates strong antioxidant capacity.

vitaminC.tip: Eat fresh for maximum vitamin C

iron.tip: The vitamin C in strawberries enhances iron absorption from other foods

pairWith.reason: Adds protein and calcium; classic breakfast combo
Romantic treat that combines antioxidants
In salads—vitamin C helps absorb spinach's iron

tips.storage: Refrigerate unwashed; wash just before eating. Best within 3-5 days
tips.selection: Bright red all the way to the stem; green or white shoulders mean underripe
tips.prepTip: Keep stems on until eating to preserve nutrients and freshness

commonMistakes: Cutting green tops off before storage (reduces shelf life)
Washing before refrigerating (promotes mold)

cautions.allergies: Strawberry allergy is uncommon but possible, often linked to birch pollen allergy
cautions.pesticides: On 'Dirty Dozen' list—consider organic or wash very thoroughly
cautions.oxalates: Contains oxalates—moderate if prone to kidney stones

strawberries.pregnancyNotes: Excellent—high folate (9% DV) and vitamin C. Wash thoroughly.

avocado.name: Avocado, raw
avocado.insight: Nature's butter—unique fruit packed with heart-healthy monounsaturated fats, exceptional fiber (10g), and more potassium than bananas.

balanced.insight: Exceptional nutrient profile: 10g fiber (36% DV), excellent potassium, folate, and healthy fats. One of the most complete foods available.

heart_health.insight: 67% of fat is monounsaturated (oleic acid)—same as olive oil. Lowers LDL, raises HDL. 727mg potassium supports blood pressure.

muscle_building.insight: Only 3g protein, but healthy fats support hormone production including testosterone. Good for bulking diets.

energy.insight: Healthy fats provide sustained energy without crashes. Good B-vitamins. Best for slow-burning energy, not quick fuel.

weight_management.insight: 240 calories is high, but the exceptional fiber (10g) and healthy fats provide outstanding satiety. Studies show they help weight loss despite calories.

brain_focus.insight: High folate (30% DV) and vitamin E protect brain cells. Healthy fats support brain structure and function.

gut_health.insight: 10g fiber per avocado is exceptional—more than most vegetables. Supports healthy microbiome and regular digestion.

blood_sugar.insight: GI of 15 and only 1g sugar—virtually no glycemic impact. Fat and fiber slow glucose absorption from other foods in the meal.

bone_joint.insight: Good vitamin K (35% DV) for bone proteins. Anti-inflammatory fats may benefit joints. Lacks calcium and vitamin D.

anti_inflammatory.insight: Oleic acid is anti-inflammatory. Vitamin E and other antioxidants reduce oxidative stress. Excellent omega-6:omega-3 ratio for a plant food.

fatSolubleVitamins.tip: Fat in avocado helps absorb vitamins A, D, E, K from other foods

carotenoids.tip: Adding avocado to salads increases carotenoid absorption from vegetables 2-6x

pairWith.reason: Classic breakfast—protein + healthy fats
Increases absorption of fat-soluble vitamins and carotenoids 2-6x
Combines two of the healthiest fats

avocado.portionVisual: 1 medium avocado = about the size of your fist; ½ avocado is standard serving

tips.storage: Room temp until ripe (gives slightly to pressure), then refrigerate for up to 5 days
tips.ripening: Put in paper bag with banana to ripen faster
tips.prepTip: Sprinkle with lemon juice to prevent browning; store with pit in to slow oxidation

commonMistakes: Refrigerating before ripe (prevents proper ripening)
Discarding slightly brown avocado (it's fine—just oxidation)

cautions.latex_allergy: Cross-reactivity possible—those with latex allergies may react to avocado
cautions.fodmap: High in FODMAPs—may cause bloating in sensitive individuals
cautions.calories: Easy to overconsume—½ avocado is typically a serving

avocado.pregnancyNotes: Excellent—high folate (30% DV) critical for neural tube development; healthy fats support fetal brain

pediatric.ageAppropriate: 6+ months (one of the best first foods)

Combines two of the healthiest fats

avocados.portionVisual: 1 medium avocado = about the size of your fist; ½ avocado is standard serving

tips.storage: Room temp until ripe (gives slightly to pressure), then refrigerate for up to 5 days
tips.ripening: Put in paper bag with banana to ripen faster
tips.prepTip: Sprinkle with lemon juice to prevent browning; store with pit in to slow oxidation

commonMistakes: Refrigerating before ripe (prevents proper ripening)
Discarding slightly brown avocado (it's fine—just oxidation)

cautions.latex_allergy: Cross-reactivity possible—those with latex allergies may react to avocado
cautions.fodmap: High in FODMAPs—may cause bloating in sensitive individuals
cautions.calories: Easy to overconsume—½ avocado is typically a serving

avocados.pregnancyNotes: Excellent—high folate (30% DV) critical for neural tube development; healthy fats support fetal brain

pediatric.ageAppropriate: 6+ months (one of the best first foods)
